Macron presses PM Lecornu to secure a budget for France
subhead: A special budgetary bill was put forward in a cabinet meeting on December 22, and is expected to be adopted by parliament on Tuesday. Prime Minister Sébastien Lecornu is still seeking a majority to pass the budget bill, though the right has encouraged him to force it through in January 2026.

With the assassination of a third Russian senior officer, the military suffers high-ranking losses
subhead: Russian investigators suspect that Ukrainian secret services were behind the car bomb attack that killed Lieutenant General Fanil Sarvarov. In 2024, Vladimir Putin called another senior officer's murder a 'serious failure.'

title: 2025 was the year AI-generated videos flooded social media
subhead: The endless streams of millions of videos generated by artificial intelligence on Instagram, TikTok, YouTube, X, Facebook and beyond have become inescapable. And users want more.

title: Cambodia-Thailand conflict: The poison of nationalism
subhead: The border the two countries share has regularly been a flashpoint for clashes. The persistent conflict has highlighted the limitations of weak multilateralism and the powerlessness of traditional diplomatic tools at a time when force has made a comeback in international relations.

title: From Barbie to Labubu, adults find comfort in collectible figurines
subhead: The craze for Funko Pop! and other Blind Box collectibles has continued to grow, driven by a generation of 'kidults,' adults who embrace their inner child, turning their homes into miniature pop culture museums. Caught between a search for identity, a significant budget and environmental contradictions, this new hobby has become a mainstream phenomenon.

Disneyland Paris at 40: When Mickey Mouse said 'bonjour' to Paris
subhead: On December 18, 1985, the Walt Disney Company approved the construction of its first European theme park in Marne-la-Vallée, about 30 kilometers east of Paris. The prime minister secured the deal after tough negotiations between envoys from the Socialist government and an American corporation seen as the embodiment of ruthless capitalism.

title: Madagascar's metalheads lead charge of anger: 'It's easier to make yourself heard when you scream'
subhead: After three weeks of protest, Madagascar's Generation Z succeeded in toppling those in power on October 14. The uprising drew much of its strength from countercultural circles, chief among them the island's vibrant metal scene. Heirs to a long tradition, Madagascar's metalheads condemn poverty, inequality and the regime's incompetence.

title: Trump and the 'derangement syndrome' driving people crazy
subhead: To discredit the president's opponents, the Make America Great Again movement has coined the phrase 'Trump derangement syndrome': a supposed mental illness that explains their systematic opposition. While the psychiatric argument for this has not been proven, many Democrats attest to the anger they feel every time the president speaks.
